body_text.text: Introduction

The muon magnetic anomaly, a µ = (g−2) µ /2, endures as an long-standing test of the Standard Model (SM), where the ∼ 3.5σ (or higher) discrepancy between the experimental measurement a exp µ and the SM prediction a SM µ could be an indication of the existence of new physics beyond the SM.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: For a SM µ , work is ongoing to improve the estimates from all sectors of the SM, where in particular the hadronic contributions limit the total precision.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Currently, the efforts of the Muon g − 2 Theory Initiative [1] and the groups involved within it show great progress and promise in improving the estimate of a SM µ and its uncertainty.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: A recent precise re-evaluation of the dominating hadronic vacuum polarisation contributions to a SM µ has resulted in a SM µ = (11 659 182.04 ± 3.56) × 10 −10 [2] (for alternative evaluations of a SM µ , see other analyses as part of [1]).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Comparing this with the current experimental world average value of a exp µ = (11 659 209.1±5.4 stat ±3.3 sys )×10 −10 [3] results in a deviation between theory and experiment of ∆a µ = (27.06 ± 7.26) × 10 −10 , corresponding to a 3.7σ discrepancy [2].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The value for a exp µ is entirely dominated by the measurements made at the Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL) [4], which achieved an overall precision of 540 parts-per-billion (ppb).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: However, efforts are currently underway to improve the experimental estimate at the Muon g − 2 experiment at Fermilab (E989) [5] and also at the proposed future J-PARC experiment [6].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: With the BNL measurement being statistics-limited, the goal of the E989 experiment is to measure a µ with 20 times higher statistics, whilst also achieving a 2-3 times improvement in the systematic uncertainty [5].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The target total uncertainty is 140ppb, which is a factor ∼ 4 improvement with respect to BNL.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Assuming the hypothetical situation of the new experimental measurement at Fermilab yielding the same mean value for a exp µ as the BNL measurement but achieving the projected improvement in its uncertainty, the comparison with a SM µ would result in a g − 2 discrepancy of ∼ 7σ [2].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The E989 experiment completed its first physics run, Run-1, during March -July 2018.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Immediately following this, a summer programme of essential upgrades was implemented, to ensure that the experiment would deliver on both its statistics and systematics goals for Run-2 and beyond.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: After briefly describing the experimental techniques employed by the Muon g − 2 experiment at Fermilab to measure a µ , this article will review the status of the experiment after the Run-1 data-taking period and discuss the outlook for the future.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Principles of the E989 measurement 2.1 Overview

Following the same methodology as the previous experiment at BNL, the Muon g − 2 experiment at FNAL injects longitudinally polarised muons into a storage ring with a magnetic dipole field | B| ∼ 1.45 T. In order to determine a µ , the experiment measures two frequencies: the frequency ω a at which the muon spin (polarisation) turns relative to its momentum and the value of the magnetic field normalised to the Larmor frequency of a free proton, ω p .

body_text.text: Producing and storing the muon beam
The accelerator complex at Fermilab was chosen due to its capability of producing a highpurity, intense muon beam, which provides an outstanding statistics advantages compared to the BNL experiment.
body_text.section: Producing and storing the muon beam

body_text.text: An 8 GeV proton beam is fired at a target to produce pions.
body_text.section: Producing and storing the muon beam

body_text.text: These pions are then injected into a delivery ring, in which the pions decay into muons via π + → µ + ν µ .
body_text.section: Producing and storing the muon beam

body_text.text: A long decay channel for the pion decay into muons is provided by ∼ 4 orbits of the delivery ring.
body_text.section: Producing and storing the muon beam

body_text.text: During this time, any remaining protons and the resulting muons are separated by enough orbital distance that the protons can be safely discarded from the beam.
body_text.section: Producing and storing the muon beam

body_text.text: The result is a ∼ 96% longitudinally-polarised µ + beam consisting of 8 × 10 6 muons/sec with an energy of 3.094 GeV/c and a π + content of < 10 −5 %.
body_text.section: Producing and storing the muon beam

body_text.text: Not only does this allow for 21 times more decay positrons to be detected than at BNL, but the minimal proton and pion contamination also reduces the hadronic flash recorded by the detectors at beam injection by a factor of 20 compared to the previous experiment.
body_text.section: Producing and storing the muon beam

body_text.text: The BNL storage ring has been recommissioned for the Fermilab experiment.
body_text.section: Producing and storing the muon beam

body_text.text: In 2013, it was transported 3,200 miles on a high-profile 35-day journey that received great interest from the wider physics community and the general public.
body_text.section: Producing and storing the muon beam

body_text.text: To safely the deliver the muons to the experiment from the upstream beam-line, the beam is injected into the storage ring through a superconducting inflector magnet, which locally cancels the ∼ 1.45 T storage B-field to allow the muons to enter without being deflected.
body_text.section: Producing and storing the muon beam

body_text.text: As can be seen from Figure 1b, the muon beam is injected onto an orbit that is displaced by 11 mrads radially outward from the ideal orbit of the storage ring.
body_text.section: Producing and storing the muon beam

body_text.text: In order to direct the beam back onto the correct trajectory requires a 'kick'.
body_text.section: Producing and storing the muon beam

body_text.text: The requirements of each of the three kickers are to produce a ∼ 300 Gauss field over 4 metres for 120 ns at 100 Hz as the muon beam pulse traverses through the domain of the kicker region.

body_text.text: To provide vertical focusing, electrostatic quadrupoles are used to confine the muon beam in the storage region.

body_text.text: Measuring the anomalous precession frequency, ω a
In the storage ring, muons decay via the parity-violating weak process µ + → e +ν µ ν e into positrons.
body_text.section: Measuring the anomalous precession frequency, ω a

body_text.text: The higher-energy positrons are preferentially emitted along the direction of the muon spin, such that the detection of the arrival time and energy of the decay positrons above an appropriate energy cut can be used to infer the spin direction and extract ω a .
body_text.section: Measuring the anomalous precession frequency, ω a

body_text.text: The primary detectors for this purpose are 24 calorimeters placed at equidistant positions on the inner radius of the storage ring, as shown by the blue rectangles in Figure 1a.
body_text.section: Measuring the anomalous precession frequency, ω a

body_text.text: These calorimeters record the oscillation in the number of detected positrons over time due to the spin precession.

body_text.text: Analysis and hardware blinding
The Muon g − 2 experiment is both hardware and software blinded.
body_text.section: Analysis and hardware blinding

body_text.text: The 40MHz that clock drives the calorimeter digitizers, straw tracker and NMR digitisers has had an offset in the range ±25 ppm applied to externally blind the time of the measured ω a .
body_text.section: Analysis and hardware blinding

body_text.text: Software blinding occurs at the analysis stage for both the ω a and ω p frequencies.

body_text.section: Analysis and hardware blinding

body_text.text: In late stages of the analysis, before a final unblinding, relative unblinding exercises of these individual offsets to a common offset are performed for all analyses and datasets, allowing for internal comparison and consistency checks without the risk of conscious or unconscious bias.

body_text.text: Current experimental status following Run-1
During Run-1, the Muon g − 2 experiment recorded 17.5 billion positrons, almost twice the number recorded from both the combined µ + and µ − runs of the BNL experiment.
body_text.section: Current experimental status following Run-1

body_text.text: The analysable data after data quality cuts (DQC) is 1.38 times that of the BNL dataset, with a projected statistical uncertainty of 350 ppb.
body_text.section: Current experimental status following Run-1

body_text.text: Figure 4a shows the accumulation of data over the course of Run-1.
body_text.section: Current experimental status following Run-1

body_text.text: Figure 4b shows the fit-to-data of 0.95 billion positrons accumulated over 60 hours in mid-April 2018, corresponding to a statistical uncertainty of 1.3 ppm.
body_text.section: Current experimental status following Run-1

body_text.text: The publication of the result from all data from Run-1 is expected in late-2019.
body_text.section: Current experimental status following Run-1

body_text.text: Studies of the performance during Run-1 showed that the muon storage was roughly half that of the original design specifications.
body_text.section: Current experimental status following Run-1

body_text.text: This was, in-part, due to an underperformance of the kicker system, which was found to have a 30% deficit in required kick strength.
body_text.section: Current experimental status following Run-1

body_text.text: Therefore, the summer shutdown that directly followed the end of Run-1 involved a substantial kicker system upgrade.
body_text.section: Current experimental status following Run-1

body_text.text: Additional upgrades were performed to the electrostatic quadrupoles and the accelerator complex.
body_text.section: Current experimental status following Run-1

body_text.text: The installation of a new open-ended inflector magnet has been planned for the end of Run-2 in the summer of 2019, which is projected to incur a further ∼ 40% increase in the number of stored muons.
body_text.section: Current experimental status following Run-1

body_text.text: Currently, the Muon g − 2 experiment is due to continue running for a further two years to obtain the full 20× BNL statistics dataset.
body_text.section: Current experimental status following Run-1

body_text.text: Conclusions and outlook
The Muon g − 2 experiment at Fermilab is undertaking the formidable task of measuring a µ with a target total uncertainty of 140ppb.
body_text.section: Conclusions and outlook

body_text.text: The comparison of this measurement with the impressive SM prediction a SM µ will determine whether the current discrepancy between theory and experiment of ∼ 3.5σ is well established.
body_text.section: Conclusions and outlook

body_text.text: In in order to evaluate a µ , the E989 experiment follows the principles of the BNL experiment to measure the muon anomalous precession frequency ω a and the magnetic field in terms of ω p .
body_text.section: Conclusions and outlook

body_text.text: The first physics run and a summer programme of essential upgrades are already complete.
body_text.section: Conclusions and outlook

body_text.text: During Run-1 alone, the experiment collected twice the number of positrons collected at the BNL experiment, which after DQC should yield a statistical uncertainty of 350 ppb.
body_text.section: Conclusions and outlook

body_text.text: The first publication of the result from Run-1 is expected in late-2019.
body_text.section: Conclusions and outlook
